Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase piglets

loan.name: Ruben

texts.en:
Ruben A. is from the village of Brgy. Paungan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 28 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. Ruben owns & operates a motorcycle transportation business. He has been engaged in his business for over 4 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month.
In 2010, Ruben joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair his vehicle to improve his service. This will be his 1st loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support his immediate family members.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to repair his vehicle

loan.name: Eliza's Group

texts.en:
Eliza A. is from the village of Sto.Domingo, Alicia, Isabela. She is 35 years old. Eliza is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Eliza is married and has 1 school-aged child. She owns & operates a livestock business, raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.
In 2009, Eliza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Eliza is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will also be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to supplement her family's income.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loan.name: Rellie

texts.en:
Rellie C. is from the village of Brgy. Homestead, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 52 years old, married and has 5 adult children. Rellie owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells personal products such as glasses and watches. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.
In 2010, Rellie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to financially support her immediate family members.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Carmen

texts.en:
Carmen B. is from the village of Brgy. Mauan, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old, married and has 5 adult children. Carmen owns & operates a vegetable selling business. She has been engaged in her business for over 13 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.
In 2009, Carmen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. She is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 2nd loan from ASKI. loan.name: Turatbek

texts.en:
Turatbek B. is 55 years old. He is married and has four children. After graduating from college and serving in the army, he worked at the local cable plant as an enamel engineer. After the death of his mother, Turatbek moved into his parents house in order to take care of his father. Since his family had been engaged in cattle breeding and land cultivating, he decided to continue this activity. He worked hard, but his earnings did not cover all the expenses for his growing children.
In 2007, Turatbek decided to start his business selling foodstuffs. This has become an additional source of income for his family. He sold part of his cattle business and rented a small shop. To maintain that shop, he obtained his first loan from Bai Tushum. This loan was used as intended and repaid without any delay.
Now, Turatbek plans to use this loan for 120,000 KGS to broaden his assortment of goods and renew his shelf stands in the rented shop. In the future, he plans to open his own shop and build a house for his family.
Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that aim to increase employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loan.use: To increase inventory assortment for shop

loan.name: Mercedes Del Milagro

texts.es: Mercedes del Milagro R. D. A., resiD. en Sensuntepeque, departamento D. Cabaas. Ella vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como agricultor, y as mismo vive junto a cuatro hijos menores D. edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Mercedes es un apersona muy responsable quien trabaja en su propio negocio en el que comercializa diversos tipos D. productos como: cosmticos, peluches, canastas, cajas y bolsas para regalo, flores artificiales y otros ms, el negocio esta ubicado en el mercado D. Sensuntepeque, y cuenta con varios clientes debido a que es una venta muy apropiada para muchas personas por el tipo D. productos que se venden. Mercedes solicita un prstamo con el enorme deseo D. surtir su negocio y D. esta forma aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en: Mercedes del Milagro R. D. A. lives in Sensuntepeque, in the departament of Cabaas. She lives with her husband, who works in agriculture, and her four young children who all attend school. Mercedes is a very responsible woman who runs her own business selling a variety of products like cosmetics, stuffed toys, baskets, gift boxes and gift bags, artificial flowers, and other items. Her business is located in Sensuntepeque's market and she has a good number of customers because the types of products she sells fit what a lot of people want. Mercedes is requesting this loan with a great desire to stock her business and thereby increase her sales.

loan.use: to buy cosmetics, baskets, toys, and other products

loan.name: Ana Rosa

texts.es: Ana Rosa P. R. de 48 aos de edad, reside en el pueblo de Ilobasco, en el departamento de Cabaas, lugar en el que vive junto a cinco hijos, todos menores de edad, los cuales se dedican a estudiar. Ana posee una venta de muecos y figuras hechas de barros, las cuales ella elabora y comercializa en su casa de habitacin, el pueblo en que Ana reside es un lugar de mucho comercio y muy conocido tanto nacional como internacionalmente por sus figuras de barro, razn por la que es un lugar de mucho turismo, lo que le da una gran ventaja a Ana. Ella solicita un prstamo a travs del cual pueda comprar mayor cantidad de materia prima, entre las que se destacan: el barro, y pinturas de todos colores. Con esto Ana espera mejorar sus ganancias y de esta forma darle una vida mejor a su familia.
texts.en: Ana Rosa P. R. is 48 years old and lives in the town of Llobasco in the department of Cabaas. She lives there along with her five children, all of whom depend on her and are in school. Ana sells dolls and figures made of clay, which she makes and sells from her home. The town in which she resides has a great deal of shops and is known nationally and internationally for its clay figures. For this reason, there is a great deal of tourism in Llobasco, which helps Ana's business. She is requesting this loan in order to buy large quantities of raw materials including clay and paint of all colors. With these materials, Ana hopes to improve her profits and in this way improve the living conditions of her family.

loan.use: To buy clay and paint to make clay figures

loan.name: Almash

texts.en:
Almash S. is 49 years old. She has four children three are grown and live on their own, and the youngest son is studying at school. She graduated from a trading college and worked as a seller in the local area.
More than 20 years ago, in order to find an additional means of subsistence for their large family, Almash and her husband decided to engage in livestock breeding. They started this business with the initial sum of 8,000 Kyrgyz Soms. With the revenues generated, they were able to give a good education to their children. In spite of the expenses of a large family, they managed to expand their herd of cattle. Today, Almashs farm has two milk cows and twenty sheep.
Almash wants to use this loan of 80,000 KGS to buy one calf and twelve sheep. With the revenues from this loan investment, Almash plans to reconstruct her house. In the future, she dreams to build a cosy house for her youngest son.
Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loan.use: To buy 1 calf and 12 sheep

loan.name: Nicols Ins

texts.es: Nicols Ins C. C., vive junto a su esposa, dos hijos y un pequeo nieto, junto a los cuales reside en Ilobasco, departamento de Cabaas. Nicols posee su propia panadera, en la cual se encarga de elaborar el pan y posteriormente comercializar tanto en su casa, lugar en el cual esta ubicada la panadera, como a sus clientes, a los cuales debe ir a repartir el pan. Cuenta con el beneficio de poseer muchos clientes los que hacen pedido en grandes cantidades y que son fieles a su negocio. Nicols solicita un prstamo a travs del cual pueda comprar harina por mayor para poder obtenerla ms barata, as como tambin manteca, azcar, miel, levadura y otros productos ms los cuales son muy importantes para la realizacin del pan. A pesar que salir adelante con su negocio ha sido bastante difcil, l ha sabido mantenerse firme con el deseo de crecer como micro empresaria y as brindarle una mejor vida a su esposa.
texts.en: Nicols Ins C. C. lives with his wife, two children, and small grandson in Llobasco, in the department of Cabaas. Nicols has his own bakery and is in charge of making bread and selling it. He sells the bread from his home where the bakery is located and to clients who distribute the bread. He has the benefit of having many clients that place orders in large quantities and are loyal to his business. Nicols is requesting this loan in order to buy flour, butter, sugar, honey, yeast, and other products that are very important for making bread at wholesale prices. Although it has been difficult for him to get ahead through his business, he has kept at his dream to grow his micro-enterprise and thereby offer his wife a better life.

loan.use: To buy raw materials to make bread

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase more merchandise for her general store

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: To purchase more garlic for resale

loan.name: Karla Liliana

texts.es: Karla Liliana S. B. de 27 aos de edad, reside en Coln, en el departamento de La Libertad, ella vive junto a su esposo quien trabaja como albail, as mismo vive junto a su nico hijo de 11 aos de edad. Karla posee una venta de ropa y zapatos para hombres mujeres y nios, la cual comercializa en el centro de Tacachico, en donde cuenta con muchos clientes a quienes les agrada ir a comprar donde Karla por los precios bajos y la calidad de la ropa. Ella solicita un prstamo a travs del cual pueda comprar ropa y zapatos por mayor de manera que pueda obtenerlos a precios menores, lo cual la beneficia porque podr obtener mayores ganancias, las cuales se vean reflejadas en la calidad de vida de su familia, la cual es su prioridad.
texts.en: Karla Liliana S. B. is 27 years old and lives in Colon, in the area of La Libertad. She lives with her husband, who is employed as a bricklayer, and their 11 year old son. Karla runs a shop in the center of Tacachico, where she sells clothing and shoes for men, women and children. She has a good base of customers who appreciate the good prices and quality of clothing. Karla is requesting a loan to purchase clothing and shoes wholesale, so that she can get better prices. This will enable her to increase her income and improve the quality of life for her family, which is her top priority.

loan.use: To purchase more inventory, clothing and shoes, for her business

loan.name: Yeni Jackeline

texts.es: Yeni Jackeline D. M. de 27 aos de edad, vive junto a su madre, dos hermanos menores de edad y un hijo de 7 aos, quien depende por completo de ella. Yeni reside en Puerto el triunfo en Usulutn, un lugar lleno de muchos turistas debido a sus hermosas playas. Ella posee una venta de productos alimenticios y de primera necesidad para el hogar, tales como: pan, huevos, leche, granos bsicos y otros ms. El negocio cuenta con muy buena ubicacin y as mismo es la nica tienda en la zona, esto le beneficia en gran manera, ya que le permite contar con muchos clientes fijos. Yeni solicita un prstamo a travs del cual pueda incrementar sus productos, de manera que pueda ofrecer ms a sus clientes. Este negocio es de mucha importantita para ella ya que es la nica fuente de ingresos con la que cuenta para sostener a su nico hijo.
texts.en: Yeni Jackeline D. Mejia is 27 years old and lives with her mother and her two younger brothers, and her young son who is 7 years old and completely dependent on Yeni. They live is Puerto el Triunfo in Usulutan, a place which is full of tourists who come for its beautiful beaches. Yeni runs a small general store where she sells snacks and groceries, and every day items such as bread, eggs, milk and others. The business has a good location and is the only shop in the area, which helps Yeni a lot, and enables her to count on a wide customer base. She is requesting a loan to purchase more products to offer her customers. This business is very important for Yeni, and it is her only source of income to care for her son.

loan.use: To purchase more products for her general store. The store provides her only source of income and lets her care for her young son.

location.town: Puerto el Triunfo, departamento de Usulutn

loan.name: Edith Del Carmen

texts.es: Edith del Carmen C. D. L., resiD. en El Transito, en el departamento D. Usulutn. Ella vive junto a su esposo y dos hijos D. 7 y 14 aos D. edad. Edith posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos comestibles y D. primera necesidad para el hogar. DesD. ya hace varios aos que cuenta con este negocio el cual le permite contar con todo lo necesario para el hogar, as como para poder pagar la mensualidad D. su casa, ya que es la herencia que con todo su esfuerzo dar a sus dos hijos. Edith solicita un prstamo por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para surtir an ms su negocio, comprando mayor cantidad D. productos que ya posee y agregando otros los cuales sus clientes solicitan. Para Edith es D. mucha importancia mejorar las condiciones D. su negocio y as mismo sus ganancias ya que la solvencia D. muchos D. los pagos del hogar, dependen del negocio D. Edith.
texts.en: Edith del Carmen C. D. Lopez lives in El Transito, in the area of Usulutan. Edith lives together with her husband and their children, ages 7 and 14. Edith has a small store where she sells every day items and groceries. For several years now she has run this business which enables her to pay for monthly household expenses. It is also a business that through her hard work, she hopes to be able to pass on to her sons. Edith is requesting a loan to better stock her store, purchase a greater quantity of products she already carries, as well as new ones her customers ask for. For Edith, it is very important that she grow her business and her income, as much of the family's economic well being depends on it.

loan.use: To purchase more products for her small general store

location.town: El Transito, departamento de San Miguel

loan.name: Juana Vernica

texts.es: Juana Vernica A. R. de 34 aos de edad, es una madre muy responsable, quien reside en el departamento de Usulutn, junto a su esposo el cual trabaja como agricultor y as mismo vive junto a sus cuatro hijos menores de edad. Juana posee una tienda en la cual comercializa productos perecederos y de primera necesidad para el hogar. Este negocio es el cual le ha permitido poder contar con ganancias extras lo que le brinda la ayuda necesaria tanto a su esposo como a ella para pagar su casa a tiempo, y as mismo contar con los alimentos y todo lo necesario para vivir dignamente. Es por esto que Juana desea contar con ms productos en la tienda, razn por la que solicita un prstamo a travs del cual pueda comprar arroz, frijoles, azcar, lcteos y otros ms los cuales son necesarios en una buena tienda. Esto es muy importante para Juana ya que cuenta con mucha competencia en el lugar, es por esto que debe contar con todo lo necesario para satisfacer a sus clientes y as ganar otros ms los cuales prefieran comprar en su negocio.
texts.en: Juana Veronica A. Rodriguez is 34 years old, and a very responsible mother. She lives in the department of Usulutn with her husband who works as a farmer and her 4 young children. Juana has a store where she sells perishable and basic needs goods for the home. This business has allowed her to count with extra earnings which she uses to help her husband, make her house payments on time, and acquire food and all that is necessary to live a life a dignity. Because of this, Juana would like to stock her store with more products, and has requested a loan through which she will buy rice, beans, sugar, dairy products, and other goods which are necessary in a good store. This is very important for Juana given that she has a lot of competition in her area, and has to have all that is necessary to satisfy her clients and gain others who would prefer to shop in her business.

loan.use: To purchase perishable goods (rice, beans, sugar, dairy products, etc)

loan.name: Rosegene

texts.en:
Rosegene N. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Sur. She is 29 years old. Rosegene is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Rosegene raises and sells pigs. Rosegene has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP for each animal.
In 2008, Rosegene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosegene has successfully repaid a previous loan of 13000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. Rosegene is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Rosegene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase young livestock to raise and sell

loan.name: Stephen

texts.en: Stephen M. N. is 32 years old and married with five children between 15 and one years old. His business is located at Bamburi Estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many, many tourist attraction sites, including the Indian Ocean white beaches. He has been selling second hand clothes for the last five years to the local people and has one employee. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more clothes to meet the high demand, especially during the Christmas season. He hopes to open up new outlets in the future and even become a wholesaler. He describes himself as trustworthy, honest and understanding.

loan.use: To buy used clothes

loan.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna S. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Sur, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 46 years old. Myrna is widowed and has two adult children. To make a living, Myrna owns & operates a business raising pigs for fattening and for sale. Myrna has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP monthly for these activities.
In 2008, Myrna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Myrna has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. Myrna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Myrna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.
About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loan.name: Abdusattor

texts.en:
Abdusattor S. is 49 years old, married and has six children. In his area of the country, cattle breeding is one of the main activities. Thats why Abdusattor decided to engage in livestock breeding also. His wife and children are the main helpers to him in this activity, as its a family business.

He started this business with 10,000 KGS and managed to broaden it with three bull-calves and three milk cows, whose milk he and his wife, Turgan, sell at the local market.

Now, Abdusattor plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to buy bull-calves and cows, which will increase their milk sales. With the revenues, Abdusattor wants to broaden his farm, which will allow him to pay for a good education for his children.

Abdusattor is a very positive and hard-working person, who believes that his efforts will lead his family to a prosperous future.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loan.use: To purchase cattle

loan.name: Angela

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Angela B. knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Angela, 57, reached elementary school. She lives in Pasay City, Philippines.
Angela presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store, in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap bars to candies and from energy drinks to rice. Having been at least nine years in business, she knows how to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most important, her customers. Monthly, she is able to earn an average of 10,000 Philippines pesos (Php).
To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 21,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. Angela plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward more profitability.
Angela's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loan.use: To buy additional stocks to replenish her inventory

loan.name: Benjie

texts.en:
Benjie B., 33 years old, is from the town of Banga. He is married and has two children aged eight and four. Benjie is a farmer who plants and harvests rice crops. He sells his harvest at his town's market. He says he started this business 13 years ago. He also owns some goats. Benjie does his best to build his business and have a stable income.
Benjie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benjie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Benjie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business.

loan.use: To buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs

loan.name: Benjie

texts.en:
Benjie is a farmer from the town of Banga, Agusan Del Sur. He is 27 years old and married. He has a one-year-old child whom he loves very much. Benjie plants and harvests rice crops that he sells at the market. He also owns a sari-sari store that his wife manages. They sell products like coffee, sugar and others. Benjie does his part to provide for his family's needs.
Benjie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Benjie has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Benjie is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to buy farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support his family financially.

loan.use: To buy farm inputs and additional merchandise to sell

loan.name: Lucia

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Lucia G. knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Lucia, 57, reached elementary school. She is a widow who raised her three working children. Together, they live in Pasay City, Philippines.
Lucia presently runs a sari-sari (variety) store in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap bars to candies and from energy drinks to rice. Having been in business for at least two years, she knows how to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most important, her customers. Monthly, she is able to earn an average of 8,000 Philippines pesos (PHP).
To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. She also plans to charge up her alkaline water business so that it will also become profitable. Lucia plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward more profitability.
Lucia's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loan.use: To buy additional stock to replenish her current inventory

loan.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is 57 years old, is widowed and lives in a place called Lower Kabete, which is off the capital city, Nairobi. She is a farmer and does crop farming. She has been farming for 10 years now and has been successful. This is her primary business, and now she wants to buy some seedlings, fertilizers and manure for the next planting season.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by an existing member and this is her third loan with KADET. She has not borrowed from other financial institutions apart from KADET.

Lucy hopes that with this loan her trade will expand and she will be able to supply farm produce to the neighboring area of Wangige and the capital city of Nairobi.

She also desires to open a green house in future.

loan.use: To buy seedlings, fertilizer, and manure for the planting season

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives on his own. He has worked as a home painter for almost 16 years, depending on customers requests. He works hard and is looking forward to developing his business in the future. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase new painting tools and products. This will enable him to take on more painting projects, increasing his productivity and therefore his sales, knowing that he obtained his first Kiva loan and it showed satisfactory results. He has been a punctual client and paid on time for the duration of his loan.

loan.use: To purchase new painting tools and products

loan.name: Dashtsermaa

texts.en: Dashtsermaa is 30 years old, married and lives with her husband and a daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. Her husband operates a taxi service in the city. Her daughter Altanzul, attends a local secondary school. Dashtsermaa operates a grocery store near her home. She is not running her business longer, but the business has been quite successful and she has gained much experience in a short time. She is a very hard-working person and says, "I would like to expand my grocery store and to open a supermarket in the future." She is requesting a loan to increase her inventory.

loan.use: To increase her inventory

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old married man living with his wife. He is from Lebanon. He has owned a small restaurant for five years and got involved in this field seven years ago. His restaurant contains a game area and he is the only person in his town who has mastered this type of business. Thats the reason why he has a good number of clients passing by his shop where they enjoy his delicious goods in addition to amusement time. Today, he is requesting to borrow $500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to renovate the game machines to attract more customers, which will enhance his financial situation.

loan.use: To renovate game machines

loan.name: Luz

texts.en:
Luz E. is a widow who lives in Purok Tan-ao, Brgy Lopez Jaena, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a buy and sell of ready-to-wear clothes business and a general store. She has four children who are 32 to 38 years old. Luz joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luz has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000, which she intends to use as additional capital for her general store and ready-to-wear clothes businesses so that she can continue to save up for future house improvements. Luz E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.
About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org. "

loan.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loan.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina P. is a 55-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fish vending business. She lives in Brgy. Bal-os, Basay, Negros Oriental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2006 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 6,000. Marcelina is now borrowing PHP 10,000 so that she can continue to fund the operations of her fish vending business. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Marcelina aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way.
About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loan.use: To fund the operations of her fish vending business

loan.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa T. is a 33-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fish-vending business. She lives in Purok San Pedro Beach, Brgy Old Sagay, Sagay City, Negros Occidental.
Leonisa has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 1994 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her fish-vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 20,000 PHP. Leonisa is now borrowing 19,500 PHP as additional capital for her fish-vending business. This will be her 15th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Leonisa aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loan.use: As additional working capital

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica L. is a married woman who lives in Poblacion, Basay, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: buying and selling tobacco and a motorcycle transport business. Her husband, Anastacio, who is 62 years old, works as a farmer to earn his living and also helps in his wife's businesses. They have eight children aged between 21 and 42.
Monica joined Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past eight loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Monica has been gradually lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 9,000 PHP, thus raising the family's standard of living. This time, for her ninth loan, she is borrowing 30,000 PHP, which she intends to use as additional working capital for her tobacco business and maintenance for her motorcycle so that she could continue to save up for future business improvements. Monica L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loan.use: To fund the operation of her tobacco business

loan.name: Hasmik

texts.en: Hasmik A. is an owner of a grocery shop catering to the locals villagers' needs. Together with her husband, she trades in fruits and vegetables, food, and household appliances. It has been already 12 years that the couple works with devotion and enthusiasm, making their only shop in the village very popular. Hasmik wants to enlarge the family business. She plans to put up additional shelves and bring more appliances, and introduce clothing to meet the clients demand.

loan.use: Expanding the business

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his mother and brother. In addition to his mothers income (who works as a home tailor), he is considered as the second and only income source of the family. He is experienced in gypsum and opened his own gypsum store in 2007. He works upon the request of his clients making different designs. Today, he is requesting $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase additional gypsum products so he will be able to increase his productivity and reach a higher level in his life. He is confident that his work will continue to be successful in the coming year.

loan.use: To purchase additional gypsum products

loan.name: Jinky

texts.en:
Jinky M. is a 41-year-old married woman who supports her family by working as a networking dealer of Avon, Natasha & MSE. She lives in Purok Paglaum, Brgy Taba-ao, Sagay City, Negros Occidental.
Jinky has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her networking business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP. Jinky is now borrowing 16,000 PHP so that she could use it as additional working capital. This will be her eighth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 16,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Jinky aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure its future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its M. to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org.

loan.use: As additional working capital

loan.name: Celestino

texts.en:
Celestino D. is from the town of Banga. He is 39 years old, married and has two children aged 12 and 5. To make a living, Celestino owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector planting and harvesting rice for sale. Celestino wishes to build a better house for his family.
Celestino joined Kiva partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Celestino has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. He is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old single man living on his own. He is from Lebanon. After seeing the need for such a business in his town, this talented man decided to open a gym in 2000. He prepared the space with the necessary equipment to offer good body building services to the clients. Over the years, thanks to his business income, he was able to develop his business and make a good profit to cover the heavy expenses of food, housing etc. Today, he is requesting to borrow $600 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to equip his gym with a new desk and closet where he can process his administrative work properly.

loan.use: To equip his gym with a new desk and closet

loan.name: Rollylyn

texts.en:
Rollylyn D. is from the village of Santa Isabel Sur. She is 35 years old, married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Rollylyn owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rollylyn has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Rollylyn joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Rollylyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

payment.comment: Over-reported by partner. Reduced to local price.

loan.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose K. is 53 years old. She is married and has six grown-up children. Her business is located at a busy market in Kakamega, known as Mudete. Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and is known as the sugar belt region.
Rose sells cereals like maize to local people. Besides selling maize, she owns a posho mill for making maize flour, which she then sells to the local people. She has been in this business for eight years now and has one employee. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is financial constraints. However, she works very hard to make sure her business does well. She is using her loan of 30,000 KES to buy more cereals to expand her business and meet the demands of her customers. In the future, she hopes to expand her business and become a supplier of cereals in the area. She describes herself as polite and ambitious.

loan.use: To purchase maize for resale

loan.name: Aliyma

texts.en:
Aliyma T. is 52, widowed and has four children. Aliyma has a higher pedagogical education, and during last 20 years, she has been working as a teacher in a local school. She is characterized by her colleagues as a responsible, precise and sociable person.

Unfortunately, salaries of the teachers in rural areas are very low. Thats why Aliyma, with her husband, decided to start their business in cattle breeding and land cultivating. They worked hard and made every effort to develop their farm. After her husbands death, Aliyma became the only bread-winner for her children, but in spite of many difficulties on her way, she was able to give a good education to all of them.

Aliyma plans to use this loan of 50,000 Kyrgyz Soms to buy more cattle. With the revenues from the loan, she plans to broaden her farm by means of livestock breeding.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loan.use: To purchase cattle

loan.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou V. is from the village of Santa Isabel Sur. She is 40 years old, married and has one adult-aged child. To make a living, Marilou owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Marilou has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2008, Marilou joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marilou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her sixth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul is a 40-year-old farmer and father of three. He has been farming for the past two years. He works hard in his business in order to provide for his family. The good climate of Kiambu has favored his farming. Paul sells cabbages from his farm in the nearby market. He hopes to become a large-scale horticultural farmer in the future. Since he joined Kiva partner, Faulu Kenya, he has managed to develop his business using his previous loans. He has now requested a loan of 80,000 KES to buy a cow and a motorbike.

loan.use: To buy a cow and a motorbike

loan.name: Anonymous Group
loan.use: To buy used clothes in bulk to offer for sale

loan.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane N. is from the village of Sta. Isabel Sur. She is 25 years old and married. To make a living, Mary Jane owns and operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3000 PHP per month from these activities. In 2010, Mary Jane joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Jane is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 2nd from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
About ASKI ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn, 41, is a strong mother who aims to become successful someday by developing her shoe-making business in the local community. Merlyn is thankful to ASHI for the loans it has provided since her membership, Merlyn has been able to support her business by purchasing required materials. She hopes to further improve her business in the future through hard work and the continued assistance of Kiva partner, ASHI.
Lack of business capital has encouraged Merlyn to ask for financial support from Kiva lenders. She will be glad if her loan request is granted and she will use the loan wisely to purchase needed supplies for her business. Her hard work and perseverance have laid the groundwork in bettering her life. Her long-term goal is to have her own shoe manufacturing shop someday. Merlyn hopes to maintain the long-term sustainability of her shoe-making business. She is very thankful that Kiva lenders through ASHI are able to share in the poverty alleviation program.

loan.use: To expand her shoe-making business

loan.name: Marisol

texts.en:
Marisol A. is from the village of Santa Isabel Sur. She is 26 years old, married and has three infant-aged children. To make a living, Marisol owns and operates a specialized retail store selling pork, fish, fruits and vegetables in the local community. Marisol has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Marisol joined Kiva partner, ASKI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marisol is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loan.name: Awad

texts.en:
Awad A. M. is a 22-year-old man from Deir A. balah in Gaza Strip. Awad opened a barber shop two years ago. Awad also inherited a house from his family and started putting on the last touches, such as painting walls and installing tiles, using the barber shop returns.
Awad came to FATEN and took a loan to purchase needed shaving and hair cutting tools as well as hair products. Awad wanted to improve the shop to secure a steady source of income, to be able to finish his house and get married.
Awad serves a big number of clients from different places in Deir A. balah. Awad appears in the picture here in his shop.

loan.use: To improve the shop and buy shaving tools and hair products

loan.name: Margarit

texts.en:
Margarit H. and her family receive the bulk of their income by working in agriculture. She has applied for a loan in order to increase the number of livestock they own. This will increase their income and will help the family get through the winter.
Margarit and her husband have two children. Margarits father-in law lives with the family as well and has great influence in childrens upbringing; his dream is to see his grandchildren well-educated and happy.

loan.use: To increase livestock

loan.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat is a homemaker with many household responsibilities. She and her husband have three daughters and a three-year-old son. Her daughters are obtaining their education at the local school. The family lives in a residential area called Lakar Mandi in Chichawatni, a small city known for its agriculture industry located in the Punjab province of Pakistan.
Nusrat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah in order for her husband to improve his dried-fruit vending business. He imports dried fruit at cheap rates from northern areas such as Murree and Sawat and sells these to his customers. Nusrat is hopeful that this investment will open new horizons of success for her husband's business and will help to improve her family's standard of living.
Nusrat is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her fifth loan application. In previous loan years, she has established a good credit record by paying her installments on time and has attended every meeting.

loan.use: To buy dried fruits to offer for sale

loan.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana A. is a widow. She sells plastic bowls and weavons at Abura. Demand for her goods is increasing and so she is requesting a loan to buy more bowls and hair products for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to build a shop.

loan.use: To buy more bowls and hair products for resale

loan.name: Basilisa

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Basilisa S. knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Basilisa, 53, reached high school. She is married to Maximiliano, 53, a vendor. Together, they live in Pasay City, Philippines.
Basilisa presently runs a buy and sell business. She offers her customers mostly footwear (shoes and sandals), fashion accessories, socks and apparel, among other things. She purchases these items at wholesale prices and sells them with minimum mark-up. Having been in this business for at least 20 years, she knows how to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in Kiva partner, CCT*, and, most importantly, her customers. She is able to earn an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP.
To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more now that the Christmas season is fast approaching. She also plans to charge up her alkaline water business so that it will also become profitable. Basilisa plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward greater profitability.
Basilisa's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loan.use: To purchase additional stock to replenish store inventory

loan.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua S. is married and has six dependants. Ekua has received senior high education. Her husband is a farmer.
Ekua has been selling kenkey at Abura for some time now. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy maize and other ingredients for the preparation of kenkey to sell in order to expand her business. She hopes to provide a meaningful education for her children.

loan.use: To buy maize and other ingredients for the preparation of kenkey for sale

loan.name: Nana Aba

texts.en: Nana Aba A. is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. Nana sells yam at Abura. She uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Nana Aba will use her loan to purchase additional yams to sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, she plans to educate her children.

loan.use: To purchase additional yams to sell

loan.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa N. sells banku (corn or maize-based dumplings, commonly known by Fantes as etew) at Abura. She is married to a farmer and has seven dependants. Adjoa has been selling banku for three years. She assists her husband in the general welfare of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more ingredients to cook and sell, in order to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her dependants.

loan.use: To buy more ingredients to cook for sale.

loan.name: Ghulam Fatima's Group

texts.en:
Ghulam Fatima is a baker and vendor of flatbreads, which she makes in a tandoor, a traditional clay oven. She has been engaged in this business for some time now and it is working very well for her. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her breadmaking business. With the loan, she will buy wood and flour in quantities that will allow her to produce a larger quantity of bread in order to fulfill the needs of her customers on a timely basis. She is hopeful that this investment will improve her business further.
Ghulam and her husband, E. M., live in a three-room brick house in a residential area called Lakar Mandi in Chichawatni, a small agricultural city of Punjab Pakistan. She moved to this area when she was married. She has many household responsibilities in addition to her business and has two daughters and a son, all of whom are pursuing their education in the local school.
She is already a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. Over the previous loan year, she has built up good credit behavior and has never missed a meeting.

loan.use: To buy wood and flour for her breadmaking business

loan.name: Felizaida

texts.en:
Felizaida R. is from the town of Banga. She is 52 years old. Felizaida is married and has 10 children. To make a living, Felizaida owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Felizaida does everything to be a good mother to her children and a good wife to her husband.
Felizaida joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felizaida has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Felizaida is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP (Philippine pesos) which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm necessities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her family financially.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loan.name: Raje

texts.en: Raje is a 22-year-old, single man, from Bet Hanon, Gaza. In 2003, Raje decided that he would like to have his own farm with just sheep. What makes this farm one of a kind is that its the only sheep farm in the area. He hopes that through this loan, he will be able to buy new sheep, equipment for the farm, and food for the sheep, which will increase his sales and at the same time increase his income.

loan.use: To buy sheep, equipment for the farm, and food for the sheep

loan.name: Muna

texts.en:
Muna is a young woman from the Gaza strip. She is the mother of one daughter and two sons. Her husband, Muhammad, is a NationA. Palestinian Authority employee. Muna's husband also has a mobile phone workshop where he fixes mobile phones.
Muna came to FATEN and took a loan because her husband needs to purchase mobile phone parts that he will use to replace broken ones when fixing mobile phones. He also wants to purchase mobile phone accessories to sell.
Muna's husband appears in the picture, as she is a conservative woman and doesn't want her picture posted online.

loan.use: To purchase mobile phone parts to fix client's phones

loan.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua O. sells cooking utensils, tomatoes and childrens wear at Abura. Efua has received education up to a Junior High School level. She is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more clothing to sell in order to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children. On the table in front of her in the picture are a little of everything that she trades in for display.

loan.use: To buy more clothing to sell.

loan.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi N. is married and has four children. Her husband is a farmer. She has received education up to a Senior High School level. Esi sells shoes and slippers at Abura, travelling from one area to another. She has been in this trade for twelve years. Esi uses her income to assists her husband in feeding, clothing and educating her children. Esi will use the loan to buy more shoes and slippers for sale to expand her business. As for the increased profits, Esi plans to reinvest them in her business.

loan.use: To buy more shoes and slippers to sell.

loan.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame T. is married and has eight dependants. Her husband is a farmer. She has studied up to a Senior High School level. Maame sells plantain and fresh pepper at Abura. Maame uses her income to assist her husband with the payment of school fees and utility bills. Maame will use the loan to purchase other types of food to meet the demand of her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to educate her children.

loan.use: To purchase new types of food to sell.

loan.name: Rochelle

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Rochelle D. C. knows this truth and grabs opportunity as it comes her way. Rochelle, 32, is a single mother of one child who is in elementary school. After finishing high school, Rochelle strived more to sustain their daily needs and to prepare financially for the future of her young child. The family lives in Pasay City, Philippines.
Rochelle runs a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells items that are needed daily by her neighbors. Products on her shelves range from bars of soap to candy and energy drinks to rice. She also manages a food stall where she sells foodstuffs to neighbors. After 18 years in business, Rochelle knows how to pay her dues. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT and, most important, with her customers. She earns an average of 10,000 Philippines pesos (Php) per month.
To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a Php11,000 loan. She intends to use this money to replenish the inventory of her store for the Christmas season and to purchase raw meat and other ingredients needed for her food vending business. Rochelle plans to take this opportunity to drive her businesses toward more profitability.
Rochelle's life is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead, and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay micro-finance loans.

loan.use: To replenish stock for her store and purchase ingredients for her food stall

loan.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa K. is married to a farmer and has four children. Adjoa prepares kenkey, a fermented maize dough, at Abura for sale. She uses her income to assist her husband in providing for the family's basic needs. Adjoa will use this loan to expand her business by buying more maize to make dough. With new profits resulting from expansion, Adjoa will reinvest in her business.
At the time of the visit, Adjoa was washing the soaked maize to prepare it to be milled into dough.

loan.use: To buy more maize

loan.name: Yann

texts.en:
Yann Y., 50, is a local rice cultivator who has been farming on her own farmland for many years. In addition, she raises a few pigs in a stall at her home.
She is married to Chouk Heang, age 51, who assists her in the business. Yann Y. and her young kid are pictured in the photograph. This couple has seven children, all of whom are single. Two of them are working in the construction field, earning an income of approximately $50 per month.
To improve her livestock, Yann Y. is taking out a loan to purchase a small pig to raise.

loan.use: To purchase a small pig to raise

loan.name: Maame Yaa

texts.en:
Maame Yaa A. is married and has four children, and she attended school through junior high. Her husband is a farmer.
Maame sells fante kenkey, a fermented maize dough that is wrapped in leaves. She has been selling this food staple at Abura for four years. Maame assists her husband in feeding and clothing their children. The loan she is asking for will be used to buy more maize to prepare kenkey for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to educate her children.

loan.use: To buy more maize.

loan.name: Lilita

texts.en:
Lilita C. is from the village of Poblacion,Sinacaban,Misamis Occidental. She is 59 years old. Lilita is married and has 3 adult-age children. To make a living, Lilita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. Lilita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Lilita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lilita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.
About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loan.name: Alecia

texts.en:
Alecia C. is from the village of Dinas,Sinacaban,Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old. Alecia is married and has 5 adult-age children. To make a living, Alecia owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating tricycle transport services. Alecia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.
In 2010, Alecia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alecia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to add additional capital to her business. Alecia is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Alecia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions her family.
About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.
*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loan.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loan.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 37 years old, married and a mother of three. For a living, she sells clothes, hand bags and fabric. She was previously operating a butchery and a cafeteria. She has been running her business for five years and she hopes to open a boutique, combined with a tailoring business, in the future. She has requested an 80,000 Kenyan shilling loan to buy fabric and shoes.

loan.use: to buy fabric and shoes

loan.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua A. is married and has six dependents. She has been through junior high school, and now she sells provisions and drinks at Abura. Her husband is a farmer.
Ekua uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She says this loan will enable her to buy more groceries for sale, and possibly to expand her business. If she is able to make extra profit by expanding her business, Ekua plans to reinvest it.

loan.use: to more groceries for sale

loan.name: Anonymous
loan.use: Home fixing and painting

loan.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua A. sells kenkey and sandals at Abura. Kenkey is a dumpling-like Ghanaian food usually made from fermented maize (or sometimes, cassava) that is formed into dough, cooked, and served with vegetable stew or soup.
Efua is married and has six dependents. Her husband is a farmer. She has had her business for five years and assists her husband financially in providing for the well-being of their family. She plans to use the money from this loan to acquire morel sandals to meet the demands of her customers. If Efua makes additional profit as a result, she says she'll reinvest it in her business.

loan.use: to acquire more sandals for sale

loan.name: Maricel

texts.en:
As the saying goes, opportunity knocks only once. Maricel B. knows this truth and grabs every opportunity that comes her way. Maricel, 36, attended college and now is married to Salvador, who works as a branch manager of a pizza chain in town. Maricel works hard to help her husband earn for their daily needs and prepare financially for the future of their elementary grade child. Together, they live in Pasay City, Philippines.
Maricel currently runs a sari-sari (variety) store, in which she sells items that are needed daily by neighbors in her community. Products on her shelves range from soap to candies and energy drinks to rice. Having been at least seven years in business, she knows how to pay her dues on time. She also has an excellent reputation with her fellow community partners in CCT* and, most important, her customers. Monthly, she is able to earn an average of 10000 Philippines pesos (PHP).
To help her continue the operation of her business, she is requesting a 20000 PHP loan. She intends to use this money to purchase more products for her store, all the more needed now that the Christmas season is here. Maricel plans to take this opportunity to drive her business toward more profitability.
Maricel is never without challenges, both in her business and personal life. Nonetheless, she stays focused on the opportunities that lie ahead and not on the failures of yesterday or the worries of today.
*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay microfinance loans.

loan.use: To replenish stock in her store

loan.name: Maama

texts.en:
Maama Y. is married and has three children. She has attained a junior high level of education. She sells cassava at Abura. Her husband is a farmer.
She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She will use the loan to purchase other foodstuffs requested by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maama plans to educate her children.

loan.use: To broaden her stock of food for resale

loan.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 19-year-old engaged woman living with her parents and three siblings. She is from Lebanon. After getting her technical degree, she started working as a private teacher in her home in 2008. Her home business income is vital to help her father who is the main income provider of the family with the expenses, in addition to helping her fiance with the wedding preparation. She teaches five students during the school season and in summer, she sticks with four of them. Today, she is requesting to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to prepare a special teaching room with equipment such as tables and chairs to offer a comfortable service for the students in addition to being able to take on more students.

loan.use: To prepare a special teaching room

loan.name: Maama

texts.en:
Maama Y. is married and has seven dependents. She cooks banku (a local dish made from corn dough) and yam at Abura and sells it by moving from one area to another.
Her husband is a farmer. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.
She will use the loan to purchase more yams to cook for sale. She plans to reinvest her new profit.
In this photo, Maama is showing the cooked yam.

loan.use: To purchase more yams to cook for sale

loan.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba A. is married and has five dependents. Her husband is a chain saw operator.
Aba sells maize at Abura. She has been in this business for ten years. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills.
Her loan will be used to buy more maize from the farmers to dry for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.
Aba is standing in front of her store room where she keeps the maize dry for sale to her customers.

loan.use: To buy more maize from the farmers to dry for sale

loan.name: Wilter

texts.en:
Wilter G. N. is a member of Jasho Letu group. Being a member of the group, she is able to save her money, share business ideas and easily access loans.
Wilter has become more focused in running her retail shop. Besides operating a retail shop, she has a van for a transport business.
She has requested a loan of 80000 KES to add to her stock of sugar, cooking fat, soap and soda.
She dreams of owning rental houses in the future.

loan.use: To add to her stock of sugar, cooking fat, soap and soda

loan.name: Anonymous
